Description: Despite the clinical success obtained with immune checkpoint blockade in many cancers, a high proportion of patients poorly respond to immunotherapy. This is especially for immunologically cold tumors, which are characterized by either poor T cell entry in the tumor (so-called desert pattern) or by T cell accumulation in the peri-tumoral stroma (excluded pattern).  In this session, we will discuss several tumor-intrinsic and extrinsic mechanisms involved in keeping T cells away from their tumor targets, including the lack of tumor cell recognition by T cells, as well as the physical/chemical constraints imposed by the surrounding stromal cells. Therapeutic strategies to counteract this exclusion phenomenon will be discussed.
SearchResultBody: ED049. T Cell Therapies in Immunologically Cold Malignancies
Title: T Cell Therapies in Immunologically Cold Malignancies
